Vol. XXV MAY, 1938 No. 5
Editorials
Merited Honor
For the purpose of honoring and uplifting motherhood the second Sunday in May is designated Mother's Day by national act. The observance of a national Mother's Day is to be commended. Prompting expressions of love and kindness this day has brought joy to mother hearts the nation over. Helping children, young and old, to a realization of their indebtedness and responsibility to "the best mother who ever lived" has expanded the joy and enlarged the characters of thousands.
People generally like to be honored but in motherhood as well as in any situation let us be honored because of genuine merit. There are as many degrees of excellence in motherhood as in any other thing in life. It is a great privilege to mother children whether they be ours by birth or circumstance. With mothering are born love, hope, pride, ambition, and many other glorious attributes of character. With privilege comes responsibility. In mothering, that responsibility is to intelligently rear our children, wisely guiding and directing them toward honorable living.
Intelligent mothering is certainly more than highly emotionalized mothering which showers love and adoration upon the child to the point of overindulgence; mothering which so sacrifices itself to the weakness of the child and justifies and upholds him when he errs; mothering which so sacrifices itself to the child that he never learns the meaning of cooperation and unselfishness. Intelligent mothering realizes that the child's future to a large extent is measured in the mother's ability to influence and direct wisely. It establishes in the home worthy ideals and standards; it teaches faith; it trains the child to conquer self; it teaches the gospel of work; it develops honesty and loyalty. It provides opportunity for the best development of the child physically, mentally, morally and spiritually. It constantly holds the child up to his best efforts.
The genuine mother reaches beyond her own, sensing her responsibility to all children. Wherever a child is found cold, hungry, in need of attention or care of any kind she renders loving and intelligent service. Mother's Day is a good day for taking stock, for reflection upon the ambitions we hold for our children and for all children, and also for consideration of the way in which we are performing our tasks as mothers. No greater honor can come to any woman than to rear a child to manhood or womanhood, reflecting her teachings in worth while and honorable living. No greater tribute does the mother ask.
Distinguished Visitors
The West has been distinctly honored in the recent visits of two distinguished women, Dr. Mary E. Woolley, and Mrs. Betzy Kjelsberg. Dr. Woolley, former president of Mt. Holyoke College and national Chairman of the People's Mandate to End War, made a strong plea for women to be active in the cause of peace. Hope for peace in the future she placed on the long range peace movement among youth "who are determined that theirs shall be a different kind of world." "Either we believe that we can build a more kind and logical world or we believe that life is but an idle dream," she declared.
Mrs. Kjelsberg, internationally prominent Norwegian social worker is Vice-President of the International Council of Women and President of the Norway Council of Women. Twice decorated by her King for service to Norway's workers she is making a tour of America to study labor and social problems. Like Dr. Woolley, she urges American women to bend every effort to keep out of war.
Both women have rendered unusual service to their native lands as well as exerting an international influence. Contact with women of such vision and influence brings an appreciation of the place women hold in the world today, and the service women are now rendering the world. It is a stimulant to all women to become active in furthering worthy causes such as peace, social reform, etc., which improve human relations.
Presiding Bishopric
The General Presidency and Board of Relief Society are privileged to have as their advisory council the Presiding Bishopric. During the administration of Bishop Sylvester Q. Cannon, David A. Smith and John Wells, the relationship has been most pleasant and of inestimable value. The clear vision of these leaders with regard to Relief Society objectives and problems, their sympathetic understanding, has enabled them to counsel with wisdom. The Relief Society is indebted to these men for the service they have rendered in furthering its work.
The new Presiding Bishopric, Elders LeGrande Richards, Marvin O. Ashton and Joseph L. Wirthlin, bring to the position the wisdom and understanding of years of service in the Church. As Church workers they have had opportunity to understand and appreciate the work of Relief Society. That the same spirit of understanding and cooperation will continue to exist there can be no doubt. We extend to these brethren the best wishes of the Relief Society Organization.

We acknowledge these with gratitude, gratitude for the talented and well trained women, gratitude for the thoughtfulness which has prompted so many kindly expressions. I have never seen a more beautiful sight or heard finer music, and to all I extend my congratulations." RESPONSE By Mabel L. Relief Society Conference April 1 and 2, 1938 By Julia A. F. Lund, General Secretary THE Annual Conference of the Relief Society was held April 1 and 2, 1938, in Salt Lake City, Utah. President Louise Y. Robison presided. The following sessions were held: Officers' Meeting, Social Welfare Department, Work and Business Department, Relief Society Magazine Department, Secretaries' Department, Music Department. Two general sessions were held in the Tabernacle. The reception for the Singing Mothers, the one for the Stake Officers, and the President's Breakfast were delightful events. The attendance was very gratifying, and included enthusiastic workers from 116 stakes and 12 missions. The following is the attendance record at the Officers' Meeting held in the Assembly Hall, Friday morning, April 1, at 10 o'clock: Mission Presidents, 12; Stake Presidents, 108; Counselors, 135; Secretaries, 67; Board Members, 404; Total, 726. The ushers were from the Salt Lake OFFICERS' and Liberty Stake Relief Societies. Among the outstanding features of the Conference were the magnificent music, and the launching of the Membership Campaign. In connection with this, special attention must be called to the membership song, "One Hundred Thousand Strong," composed by Beatrice F. Stevens of the General Board of Relief Society. The "Rallying Song" was introduced by a double trio from the Ensign Stake, directed by Ruth Jensen Clawson, and a talented group representative of Relief Society members with Jean H. Wesseman as accompanist. Others whose talents in music added much to the meetings were Lily Priestly's organ prelude. Inez Robinson Preece's quartet, and the beautiful solo by Eliza Bringhurst. The combined choruses of Relief Society Singing - Mothers, directed by Charlotte O. Sackett, with Alta B. Cassity and Frank Asper as accompanists, made Relief Society history. MEETING GREETINGS AND OFFICIAL INSTRUCTIONS By President Louise Y. Robison MEETING with the devoted leaders of Relief Society is a continued source of joy and inspiration. REFERRING to the ruling on donations received by Visiting Teachers, we feel more strongly than ever that all donations collected by Visiting Teachers belong in the Charity Fund. If members of Relief Society or others wish to contribute to the General Fund, we shall be most grateful to them if they will give or send such contributions to the President or Secretary of the Relief Society. WE would like to emphasize the request that officers refrain from using Relief Society for advertising purposes. The fine project for better methods of laundering clothes brought many offers from soap manufacturers for demonstration in Relief Society. We are quite opposed to having any commercial article featured in our meetings. WE have received many compliments from the General Authorities of the Church, morticians, and from Relief Society Presidents on our suggestion that funeral flowers remain undisturbed until after the mourners have gone from the building. We were advised to take this action by members of the General Authorities. IN a few of our stakes, a charge is made for luncheon served on Work and Business day. We hope you will find some other way of obtaining finances. Many of our sisters would be happy to pay for their luncheon, but in each ward there are fine, faithful members who cannot afford this expense and who will not feel comfortable in attending these meetings. "THERE are occasionally Ward Presidents who do not work in harmony with their Stake President. They do not attend Union meetings and feel that they need no advice in the conduct of the Relief Society work. This is a serious condition. There must be complete harmony between stake and ward officers or the work of Relief Society suffers. Before any woman accepts an office in any department of Relief Society she should know what the requirements are and be willing to live up to them. Unless ward officers give loyal support to stake officers, they cannot expect loyalty from their own group. Remember always that the spirit of the Lord is with us only when there is harmony and a desire to cooperate for the good of the whole group. WE have had a wonderful response to the hurried request sent from our office a week ago for RELIEF SOCIETY MAGAZINE 325 a report on what the Relief Society had done for Church Security, The Presiding Bishopric asked us to get the report for the First Presidency to use at Conference. Within a week, ninety-nine stakes and missions had reported. Although the Southern States Mission is so far away our Mission Mother, Sister Clayson, had her report in the office on time. N making the survey for the clothing requirements of our people Relief Society has discovered some families in urgent need at the present time. In a few cases the bishops have requested the Relief Society to supply those needs from their funds. Evidently these bishops are new in the work, as Relief Society has not now, nor ever has had, sufficient funds to care for rent, light, food and clothing. Relief Society offers service. Our funds are to be used in cases of emergency and to supplement the work of the bishop. HERE are some very fine organizations outside of our Relief Society who are working for the benefit of humanity. We are eager to have our Societies cooperate in spreading useful information but we are opposed to having regular Relief Society class work interfered with or having dues to any other organization collected in our meetings. To'the extent that individual members can subscribe to these helpful movements we are in hearty accord, but this is entirely outside of the Relief Society. WE advise Relief Societies to cooperate with the Agricultural Colleges, with the county agents and demonstrators in any state in which they reside. These trained people have valuable information on the needs of the body and the kinds of 326 food which supply those needs. Deficiency diseases, which result from improper diet, are as great a menace as the contagious diseases. To understand the chemical requirements of the body and to know the foods which supply those needs is of great importance to mothers. WE are making a change in the Relief Society Magazine Honor Roll awards. Instead of all Relief Societies competing on the same basis, there will be three groups. One group will include all wards and branches with membership up to 49 inclusive. One group will be those Societies whose membership is from 50 to 99 inclusive, and a third group will include those with a membership of 100 or over. We feel this is more just. Presidents will please appoint a member of the Board to be responsible for the activities of ward Magazine Agents. We have had heartbreaking experiences when some of the ward Agents, who have worked RELIEF SOCIETY. MAGAZINE very hard to get subscriptions, have sent their reports to the stakes and the stakes have failed to get the information to headquarters in time for the credits to be awarded. E acknowledge with deep appreciation the very interesting publications which come to us from the missions. One recently reached us from Sister Nibley of the Northwestern States Mission with some very fine reports. The Northern States Mission sends them to us frequently. They are most helpful. Sister May Green Hinckley of the Northern States Mission gave us the very fine idea of placing useful Relief Society information on the back of our membership cards. We shall adopt this suggestion when we print other cards. May the Lord bless you with vision to see the needs, and health to carry forward the work in a manner pleasing and acceptable to yourselves and to our Heavenly Father. ANNOUNCEMENT By President Louise Y. Robison THE Government has appointed Miss Daisy Duncombe to make a survey of the hard of hearing who are living in Utah. If you know any persons who are hard of hearing, please advise them to communicate with Miss Duncombe, 1259 Sherman Avenue, Salt Lake City, giving information relative to age, sex, and education. On the whole the work has been excellent, but some which was sent in could not be accepted. Work must be examined by the stake Work and Business leader before being sent to the shop. When the work has once been accepted by her, other articles of the same kind may be sent without her accepting then, but any new type of article must be taken to her for approval. III. ORIGINAL WORK. The articles which sell best are the ones with some distinctive feature and originality, providing they are artistic and well made. Stamped articles, such as anyone can buy at the department stores, do not sell well. IV. PATENTs. The material must be good and the handwork fine No article will be accepted which is a copy of articles already in the shop. I. DUES. The dues for Mormon . PRICING. The articles should be priced by the person sending—the price that she wishes for the article. The shop will then add 25% to her price for overhead. No handwork will bring wages such as is paid by the hour for work outside the home. This is an opportunity for women to stay in the home and supplement the family income. Our motto is: “A little profit in a little time not wasted.” VI. CONTROLLING THE SUPPLY. There are now about three hundred and seventy-five women participating. Some means must be taken to control the supply. Before any thing is is sent to the shop, the stake Work and Business leader should write and ask if there is room for it. FROM CORNER STONE TO KEYSTONE By Rae B. Barker. ONE sweep of the mind carries us from March 17, 1842 to March 17, 1942. In these two dates, and the two significant events associated with them, we find the impetus for our present Relief Society Membership Campaign. On that original Relief Society birthday a little handful of women gathered to hear the plan conceived by the Prophet Joseph Smith. With him they built the foundation and laid the corner stone of our great organization. That is now history—we are still making history. The momentous event of the one-hundredth, or centennial, birthday is but a short time off. We are anticipating that date with eager interest for it is our keen ambition to be one hundred thousand strong by that time. The time is ripe to launch a big membership building program. There is an underlying purpose in this campaign which is much deeper than the mere enrollment of numbers. That purpose is to build Latter-day Saint women, and_ to strengthen our organization so that it can serve in ever wider fields. The strength and power of Relief Society is measured by the number of women it serves. How great can be the force of an ever increasing membership of spirited workers, positively charged with a desire for intellectual and spiritual growth, with high moral standards, and with the desire to serve others! The magnitude and scope of such a force not only improves the morale and fiber of our Church, community and nation, but it strengthens the individual so that with greater assurance she may meet the ever changing conditions of this interesting age. In 1842 we numbered only eighteen. By the end of the first year our membership had increased to about one thousand. By the end of the 75th year (1917), our numbers had increased to approximately fifty thousand. Then came the war period with its increased demands for welfare service. The result? Our rate of increase was about four times as great as it had previously been. During the past fifteen years, our growth, even though it was not as pronounced as during the war period, has continued steady and sound. What of the next four years? Spotlight of Attention RELIEF SOCIETY wants to do big things. In the next four years we want to definitely accelerate our rate of growth. The present tempo of living is much faster than it was a century ago. Consequently, we expect big things to be done in a short time. Interest usually follows attention; so we are turning the spotlight of attention upon the challenging problem of increasing our membership. Shall we be One Hundred Thousand strong by 1942?. Let us emphasize the strong, for we must continue to build substantially, always maintaining and elevating the high standards that have formed the foundations of this enduring structure. We must build for permanency. General Plan THAT shall be the general approach to our problem? Growth and building seem to connote the same thing. The membership campaign is in. Every sense a building program. Down through the years many, RELIEF SOCIETY CONFERENCE many women, each finding personal satisfaction and each making a personal contribution, have in the aggregate been building a serviceable "living monument". The arch has been chosen to symbolize this monument, and we will set out to complete this particular membership arch. Significance of Corner Stone and Keystone A LITTLE about the construction of an arch may be of interest. Two terms used to designate important features of the structure are the corner stone and the keystone. The tradition of the corner stone is common knowledge. Often within the corner stone are sealed historical information, resolutions and ideals. The significance of the keystone may not be so commonly known. We often hear of a key man—one who is so important that he is indispensable to his organization; or a key situation—a situation upon which other conditions hinge. The keystone is just as vital to the arch. It is the center of the crown of the arch, and, being the last member to be set in place, is regarded as binding the whole together. Thus the strength and solidarity of the arch depends upon the keystone. Use of the Keystone F, in the next four years we can average a 3314% increase over the 1937 enrollment of about 75,000, we can reach the 100,000 goal. For example, if a stake with a present enrollment of 300 increases to 325 the first year, to 350 in two years, and to 400 in four years, it will have reached its objective. Any stake, ward or mission making its 3314 9% increase in four years will have achieved "keystone success." 329 Plan WE are immediately concerned with a plan that will help us reach our objective. Since we are looking ahead to 1942, a four-year program suggests itself. Our four-year theme is "Building the Membership Arch." The slogan, which we hope will be lavishly used to make our people Relief Society conscious, is: Members Old, Members New, One Hundred Thousand by 42. For psychological reasons, short plans are best. So, the four-year plan will be broken up into one-year plans. Fundamentals in any Campaign HERE are certain fundamentals which are important to the success of any campaign. First: A name, or theme can serve a real purpose. Second: A short time for an intensive drive is most successful. Third: Competent leadership is necessary. Fourth: The use of showmanship is decidedly important. Fifth: Follow-up work is essential to success. Sixth: There should be a simple and effective system of awards. Theme THEME can transform an uninteresting matter-of-fact subject into something of special interest. An idea becomes concrete enough to attract attention. It identifies. A theme serves also as a motif which lends itself to featuring. A theme appropriate to this year's membership activity is ""New Construction." We leave it to you as stakes and wards to develop this idea of new construction in your own way. We might keep in mind that, 330 as always, the ward is the actual building site, and that quality materials and skilled labor are of utmost importance to the success of the project. Short Time Drive INTEREST fades to the vanishing point if a drive continues too long. The 1938 campaign will be launched with the opening of Relief Society next fall, and the drive will end on December 15th. All reports can and should be in the general office with the regular annual reports. Competent Leadership NO drive can be very successful without competent leadership. More will be said on this point under the heading of "Personnel." Showmanship SHOWMANSHIP is the art of dressing up an idea. By this means, a point may be stressed in a more effective way than by the use of words alone. Everyone likes a show, enjoying the play atmosphere. Often we are willing to work hardest at our play. "We are visual minded. Eye impressions stick." An old Chinese proverb says, "One time seeing is worth one thousand times hearing." You will find many opportunities for the use of showmanship: in publicity features, stunts, displays, progress charts, etc. For instance, to visualize the progress being made, one suggestion might be to use an arch designed as a picture frame, and mount on it snapshots of new members as they join your group. Much interest and fun might be stimulated by selecting "catchy" snapshots where possible. RELIEF SOCIETY MAGAZINE Follow-Up Work "THE value of consistent, quiet, follow-up work can hardly be overemphasized. To illustrate: A progressive group of executive officers invited all Relief Society members, both active and inactive, and all women who might be potential members, to a delightful "At Home." It was given in the president's home. For several weeks following, an increase in attendance was noticed at the weekly meetings, but it was not permanent. Perhaps some definite follow-up work would have paid big dividends on the initial investment; personal visits, perhaps leaving a magazine to be called for on a second visit, etc. Awards AWARDS of various kinds have long been used to stimulate interest and activity. We might pass on this interesting observation from Mr. Zenn Kaufman who, from his wide experience in conducting sales contests, says that the honor award —the satisfaction in succeeding— seems to be a greater incentive to work than material or monetary awards. There will be many opportunities to stimulate ward activity through awards offered by the Stake Boards. Personnel WE have always worked to increase membership, but concentrated work on membership is a new departure. Careful preliminary planning will be necessary before actual work begins. For best results the main responsibility should be fixed on some one individual in each stake and ward. It is advised that a member of each Stake Board be assigned as Stake Membership Coordinator for RELIEF SOCIETY CONFERENCE this drive, and that she be relieved of other special duties as far as possible. Where a board is not already too large, and where some particular woman, not now a member of the Stake Board, seems to have outstanding qualifications for managing such a campaign, she might be added to the board for this particular work. Likewise in each ward, a woman especially qualified for the work should be chosen as Ward Membership Coordinator. This ward appointment could be made for the period of one year, and where desirable, the same person could be re-sustained the following year. The coordinator, whether of the ward or stake, should, of course, work in close touch with the presidency. May we impress the thought that this calling is an important one, for the success of the project depends in large measure upon the ability of those who plan, coordinate, and direct the drive. Coordinators should be chosen with the following qualifications in mind: 1. A projective personality; some one genuinely interested in people; one whose friendliness is felt. 2. Someone who can approach the work with sound enthusiasm and who has a zest for tackling problems. The person with an original idea and who is afire with enthusiasm is an inestimable power. 3. Executive ability; the ability to plan, to organize, and to make the plan work. We must all be good saleswomen. A good saleswoman is one who knows the A B C's of her product —in this case Relief Society work— and then has the ability to interest her prospect in trying it. As representatives of Relief Society, are we familiar with: 1. The course of study. 331 2. The use of membership dues. 3. The significance and benefits of welfare work. 4. The duties and opportunities of visiting teachers. 5. Some of the outstanding services rendered by the general organization for community, national and international welfare. Do we know, for instance, the part played by Relief Society in improving local health conditions; the food conservation and Red Cross work done by Relief Society organizations during the World War? Having the above mentioned information is a part of preparation in the art of securing members. Department In Union Meeting THE coordinators should be appointed at once, as considerable time is needed for effecting concrete workable plans. Will the Stake Presidents please note the need of a department in Union meetings. Coordinators and Existing Groups THE existing groups of Relief Society officers make a splendid set-up to carry on the membership building program. Each of the groups in the various departments will be asked to handle some part of the drive: executive officers, class leaders, work and business leaders, enlistment committee, and visiting teachers. The stake and ward coordinators should jointly plan the work of the intensive drive. It will be the definite responsibility of the ward coordinator to meet with each group, plan with them which phase of the work they can handle best, and see that it is carried out. 332 The responsibility may sound heavy, but the most successful executive is an artist in sharing the work. There is a real advantage in delegating much of the work. Every woman used is another one interested. Stress the importance of dividing the work. Opening the Campaign WITH regard to actually launching the work, it is suggested that the executive officers open the campaign, perhaps with a guest day, or with any function which suits best. Keep in mind the fact that you will have to create your own atmosphere—one of enthusiasm. The Work and Business day offers opportunities for fruitful contacts through social functions. Since the enlistment committee in many wards acts as a standing hospitality committee, these two groups might work together on a social occasion. The details of plans to be used with each group will take shape as you get into the work. We are sure you will find it challenging to your resourcefulness. Sales Talk IF we examine the assets column of the Relief Society ledger, we will find many values accruing to its members. We are affiliated with a women's organization of national and international standing. Alone, any one person's influence would be negligible in solving a community problem, but the organized strength of many women can be, and is, a real power. Relief Society is democratic; its doors stand open to all women of high purpose. It offers a broad scope RELIEF SOCIETY MAGAZINE of opportunity for personal development. The rise of adult education is an indication of the sweeping urge for more culture. For many women, Relief Society has been a serviceable instrument in satisfying the need for complete development, head, hand and heart. A vital part of our work is to concern ourselves with the wellbeing of others. Through this phase of the work we increase our capacity to love one another—a rare virtue. One of our greatest assets is that we are auxiliary to the Priesthood of the Church. Our organization is unique among women's study groups in that it offers an opportunity for religious study, thus crystallizing our spiritual concepts and nourishing our faith. Merit is eventually reflected in our membership rolls. To merit what we want, is to attract more women; we must always be rediscovering Relief Society, reexamining our general practices, and making opportunities to be friendly. We must discover our women's talents and interests, and make use of them. We must find our strength, sense our weaknesses, and overcome our handicaps. We have set out to do a big piece of work by 1942, but this is a day of stupendous achievement. We aim for "keystone success." Let the spirit of gathering spread among the women throughout the entire Church, and let this be our creed—Faith to Succeed. The address given by Rena B. Maycock in the in the Officer's Meeting will appear in a later issue of the Magazine. RELIEF SOCIETY CONFERENCE 333 WORK AND BUSINESS DEPARTMENT Lalene H. Hart, Chairman RESULT OF WORK AND BUSINESS PROJECT By Lalene H. Hart WHEN something has been accomplished everyone is ready to declare it was easy, but before it is begun they say it is impossible. This was somewhat the feeling many of our Relief Society women had when our Work and Business Project was launched Jast April. All the difficulties of such an enterprise were seen at once, yet, a thing well begun is half done, and moreover, the surmounting of: the first barrier gives courage and strength for those following. This proved to be the case with our project. In order to get definite and tangible information as to the contribution our organization is making in its legitimate field of economics and family relationship we asked that a survey be made with two objectives in mind, first, to supply factual data to verify or challenge general statements about present day family life; second, to help women to understand and evaluate their own work and problems. The following is a brief summary of that survey: No. Of stakes reporting, 99; No. Of stakes participating in project, 94; No. Of stakes reporting more than 50 per cent of membership participating, 35; No. Of wards reporting, 849; No. Of wards participating, 720; No. Of women making bread, 84 per cent, 25,459; No. Of women doing sewing, 75 per cent, 24,485; No. Of women doing launering, 92 per cent, 28,832; No. Of women carrying on project in bread making, 64 per cent, 5,652; No. Of women carrying on project in sewing, 61 per cent, 4,342; No. Of women carrying on project in laundering, 76 per cent, 5,836. The figures show that more women do their own laundering than other activities. Only 50 per cent of women were interested in the project at first, but as it progressed more became active. Many liked the discussions and the actual work, but did not want to keep records or file reports. Demonstrations, lectures, discussions, exhibits, contests, debates, visits to flour mills and laundries were some of the methods used to put over the project. To the question of what definite value the project was such answers as these were given: It has created an interest in women's problems, and a desire to do more efficient, scientific and professional work. More wholesome and better bread is being made and used than ever before. Non-members have become interested with the result that they want to know more about Relief Society work. All the women participating agree that it is more economical and satisfying to create and do things at home. While our objectives have not been fully realized, the project has been very much worth while, and is more far reaching than we know. Since many women feel they are just home makers and these activities too commonplace to be studied, Work and Business leaders have a big opportunity to help them to be the very best home makers. This department is comparable in its cultural value to the other prescribed courses, and requires thorough preparation in making it one of the best departments in the Relief Society. It can be done! 334 RELIEF SOCIETY MAGAZINE SUGGESTIONS FOR WORK AND BUSINESS FOR 1938-39 By Donna D. Sorensen FROM the beginning of our organization sewing for the needy has been, and probably ever will be, the most important obligation of the Work and Business department. This activity should never be neglected. However, in response to repeated demands which have come from the stakes for additional help in planning for this day the General Board will print in the July Magazine nine topics for discussion for the coming year on the "Selection and Preparation of Food for Proper Nutrition." Under each of these topics will be given the names of various pamphlets and addresses where these may be obtained. No lessons will be written and the way the stakes and wards utilize this material in the Magazine will be largely left to them. However, the General Board suggests:
1. That the use of this material be optional in the wards and may be used in connection with the traditional activities of the day.
2. That this matter of nutrition is worthy of serious consideration by the wards of the Church as it is timely and worth while.
3. That if any additional material or any other subject be selected by the wards it must be presented by the ward Work and Business leader to the stake for its approval and at any event any subject selected must be on some phase of homemaking. Book reviews or any program on any subject other than home making are out of order on Work and Business day.
4. That the stake Work and Business leader will be responsible for obtaining the pamphlets for her various wards and obtain them early enough to distribute at the Union meeting preceding the day they will be utilized.
5. That if this material on nutrition is used in the wards that the treatment of it be considered in an informal manner with the idea of having an interchange of the thoughts and opinions of all the women present, rather than presenting the material as a formal lesson.
6. That in wards where this material is considered the ward counselor in charge of Work and Business and the ward Work and Business leader consult, and conjointly choose a woman to lead in this informal discussion on Work and Business day. A different woman will be chosen to lead the discussion each month, thus distributing the responsibility and bringing more women into activity. We suggest that each of these women chosen be asked to attend the Union meeting where the pamphlets on her subject for discussion will be distributed.
7. That if the wards in a stake choose to discuss this subject of nutrition the stake leader of Work and Business give it some consideration at Union meeting and the time and emphasis be left to the discretion of the stake leader.
PLANNING FOR SOCIABILITY
Nellie O. Parker
Sociability is an important gateway to an abundant life. The more we use this gate and extend our friendly contacts the more we enlarge our world.
"The world stands out on either side No wider than the heart is wide."
RELIEF SOCIETY CONFERENCE
Friendship is one of the sweetest things in the world. The intellectual and spiritual things we share with others make us richer. The more we give away of this spiritual wealth the richer we are.
Social recreation of any type that helps us enjoy fellowship with one another and gives an opportunity for growth, opportunity to be and become one's self, and to have joy in living is very desirable. It is fundamental to our nature to crave companionship. We get pleasure from doing things together. Even hard work is enjoyable when done in a group—for example, a ward dinner or community fruit canning. We experience recreation of spirit in singing and playing together, and when we share food with one another we obtain a completeness of sociability that nothing else seems to give.
We should aim to make our Relief Society contacts as friendly as possible. Let us think about what others are interested in and try to make them happy. This is a vital element of true etiquette. Assign certain members to welcome everyone who comes to meeting. Strangers and visitors should be given special attention and introduced at least to those by whom they are seated. Let someone look after their comfort and see that they enjoy themselves.
We recommend that Work and Business day be made a happy social day, a sewing circle linked to a party spirit with an atmosphere of informality, insuring free and easy discussion and a feeling of friendly cooperation. Secure constructive conversation by directing it in proper channels to correlate with the project in hand. See that everyone feels she is a vital part of the organization. Plan the social hour so that everyone takes her turn in helping when luncheon or refreshments are served. Give thought to planning the social hour; draw on your originality; vary your menus; have little surprises and glorify the common things, but keep them simple and within the reach of the frugal purse. Keep abreast of the times.
If members, especially leaders, will radiate their enthusiasm and give their best thought to Relief Society, planning ahead and looking forward to it as one of the big things of their lives, they will stimulate interest and enthusiasm in others. Everyone will want Relief Society; it will gain in prestige. Those who work in the organization love it enthusiastically. Our problem is to give everyone something to do. The good leader will divide work, getting as many to participate as possible. Make an important occasion of the installation of new members, and also the welcoming back of inactive ones into active service again. Let someone sponsor the prospective member and make a little talk in her behalf, telling of her interests, talents and achievements. During the social hour the new members can be the honored guests. Everyone should meet them and extend a friendly hand in welcoming them into the Society.
For festive days plan decorations that are typically "our own." We have great ideals and traditions, we have only to work out our own symbols. Let us encourage originality and artistic talent. Let us make Relief Society very alluring and desirable, remembering that those who serve Relief Society most, love it best.
RELIEF SOCIETY MAGAZINE
MAGAZINE DEPARTMENT
Belle S. Spafford, Chairman
SERVICE AND SELLING
By Vida Fox Clawson
A good magazine representative must first have the ambition to place the Magazine in the home of every Latter-day Saint. She must think about it. Why should it go into the home of every Latter-day Saint? In the first place, the very fact that it is there testifies that the home is a home of culture and the mother discriminating in her taste. The fact that it is there increases the faith of the children. Even if they don't read it, it is good for them to have the Magazine in the home.
This is a day when the good and the bad are so closely intertwined that it is difficult to choose the right. For example, we listen to a glorious radio rendition of Aida or some grand opera, and we are uplifted, then we realize that the sponsors are perhaps cigarette advertisers. This advertising is very subtle but very effective. Few of us realize the effect of it. After months of such advertising, we become used to the thing which at first shocks us. We say, "Well, I guess it's all right. I guess it isn't as harmful as we thought it was." We grow less and less rebellious.
The same thing happens to the boy who learns to admire the editor of a magazine through reading his editorials, and then some day perhaps he sees a picture of this man with a cigarette in his hand. The boy, if young and brought up according to Mormon ideals, is shocked. But he begins this process of thinking, "Well, I guess it's not so bad after all," and finally gets to the point where he thinks it is not so wrong to smoke.
The more magazines advertising tobacco, liquor and things of that kind which we have in our homes the more we need the Relief Society Magazine as a supporting anchor, for it comes to us absolutely unpolluted, not only in its articles but in its advertising.
It is difficult these days to choose the right from the wrong. Right now you and I would have no definite convictions about this life and the life to come if we didn't feel that we are being led by divine leadership, inspired leadership. Those who have the publication of this Magazine in charge are inspired women. How grateful we should be to have this Magazine come into our homes and how eager we should be to carry the news to others.
A good representative should feel it just as much a mission to sell the Magazine and place it in every Latter-day Saint home as any missionary who goes out into the field.
Let us take a peek into some of the Magazines. Suppose there is a boy who is in his early teens and is just a little bit wayward. His companions are not always what his mother wants them to be. He picks up the Magazine and sees this one little sentence, "No man can be provident of his time who is not prudent in the choice of his company." This makes an impression upon the mind of that boy and he becomes more careful in the selection of his companions. If you had been the representative to place the Magazine in that home, don't you think you would have rendered a real service?
Suppose you have a neighbor who for some reason cannot make ends meet, nevertheless she buys the Relief Society Magazine, and a few months later when she meets you, she says, "You know when I bought that Magazine, I made a real investment. In the September number there was an unusually easy and good recipe for whole wheat bread. I never had baked before. It was so delicious and the family liked it so well that I just formed the habit of making my own bread. It's just unbelievable, but that little Magazine has paid for itself over and over again with just that one recipe." Wouldn't you be thrilled?
Now suppose that some one, as I did, came across the title, "Home Scriptural Reading," and thought, "We don't do enough of that in our home, but we are going to gather around the fireside every day and read the scriptures." Wouldn't you be happy if you had been the woman fortunate enough to place the Magazine in that home?
"By their fruits ye shall know them." This is just as true of magazines as it is of persons. What kind of women read the Relief Society Magazines? They are the salt of the earth. Reading the Relief Society Magazine helps every person to form a better life.
"By their fruits ye shall know them." What kind of women are they who publish the Relief Society Magazine? They are the salt of the earth. What a privilege it is for you and for me to come in contact with such women, and I sometimes think that they let us look into their souls much more distinctly through their writing than through any other source. In the January issue of this year two women whom I have known and loved for a long time have permitted me to see both of them better—Mary Connelly Kimball, the Editor of the Magazine for a long time, and Sister Talmage, a constant reader and an occasional contributor. These two women are the type of women whom we contact through the Magazine. It is a great blessing.
God bless the women who gather together and bind the lessons, the editorials, the stories, the poems, month after month, into a magazine worthy of our best selling efforts.
ACHIEVING THE GOAL
By Rose H. Neeley—Ensign Stake
When called to work on the Stake Board, my President told me my work would be with the Magazine. After careful checking with the wards, we found the subscription list low and felt that we had work ahead of us in building it up. Each chain is as strong as its weakest link and we had no desire to be the weak link in our organization.
The ward Agents were called together in Union meeting and plans made. We felt that we must become fully acquainted with the contents of the Magazine in order to present it intelligently to our subscribers. We arranged a program which was very helpful to us, and which we still follow. We have roll call which is answered by a verse or quotation taken from the Magazine, then an article, story or poem given by a member. This helps in our study of the Magazine. We have reports on what each ward is doing in regard to renewals, etc. We have discussions, and study instructions given us by the General Board.
Our aim is for each ward to go over 100 per cent each year. When we began this work we had less than 50 per cent of our members taking the Magazine. When our 1937 drive was completed we had a stake percentage of 96, with six wards over the top and the other two wards on the 75 per cent roll. We have two wards that have gone over the top each year for the past six years.
We thank our Heavenly Father for the help and inspiration He has given us; also our Stake Board, ward officers, and members who have so loyally supported us, and the ward Agents, fine, dependable sisters who work so faithfully throughout the year.
ACHIEVING THE GOAL
By Clara B. Wright—Salt Lake Stake
As a group in Union meeting we have studied the pamphlet, "Instructions To Magazine Agents." We have spent several Union meetings in intensive study. By our first Union meeting we have prepared and handed to President Williams a year-round program. In February our Stake Secretary gives us the entire individual ward enrollments. As a group in Union meeting we take these figures by wards and analyze them to find out just how much work has to be done each month, as we feel that it takes twelve months to accomplish our work. By carefully watching subscriptions we are able to secure large percentages.
A yearly report is compiled by the Stake at the close of the year and on the day that we make our awards in Union meeting this report is handed to the ward Magazine Representative who in turn takes the report to her President. We have found this has been a stimulus for effort the next year.
To illustrate: The Seventeenth Ward has an enrollment of 175 for 1938. Their total 1937 Magazine subscriptions were 123. Since October 1937, they have secured ten new subscriptions which makes a total of 133 subscriptions. 175 total enrollment minus 133 subscriptions equals 42 subscriptions to obtain in order to reach 100 per cent. From March to October is six months, and 42 divided by 6 equals 7 new subscriptions to be obtained each month. Of course we must not lose one active subscription. To guard against this we carry a pocket note book record of all subscriptions.
Special ward activities were used in achieving the goal. In one ward the President worked with the Representative. By interesting non-members of the Relief Society in the Magazine and by receiving small contributions here and there they were able to place 11 subscriptions in homes where the Magazine had not been before. The Relief Society gave eight subscriptions to retired Visiting Teachers from money taken from the General Fund.
In another ward the President and Magazine Representative called for volunteer service during the summer months in the cause of Magazine work. Another ward gave as a Christmas gift a year's Magazine subscription to each of the six oldest members of their organization.
In several of our wards the Presidency and Magazine Representatives have gone out in the interest of increased membership and the Magazine and have been more than successful.
In three years through these and other activities we have been able to raise our percentage from 21 per cent to 85 per cent, and we feel that it has been worth while.
RELIEF SOCIETY CONFERENCE
KEYNOTES TO SUCCESS
By Marcia K. Howells
One's best effort produces happiness, and usually makes for success. One Magazine agent traveled seventy-five miles in one day to visit three families and found them eager for the Magazine. Another took fruit and vegetables from those who could not pay cash. She also reported an exchange of work, such as washing or cleaning, for subscriptions.
Realizing the privilege of making friends and influencing other lives overcomes obstacles. "Sacrifice brings forth the blessings of Heaven."
Quoting from Magazine agents:
"You have to work enthusiastically, efficiently, and unselfishly."
"This year I obtained three subscriptions that I have been working on for six years. It takes real perseverance and lots of walking. I am willing to go a long distance and spend a lot of time to get one subscription. I love the work."
"I've visited returned missionaries; in every case they were glad to send the Magazine to friends in the mission field."
From Alaska: "I received the sample copies of the Magazine. I loaned them and they did the work. I didn't care to be the only one in 'Uncle Sam's Attic' enjoying our wonderful Magazine."
One of the missions reports: "I have in mind a conference where some of the members have never had the opportunity of going to school and the Relief Society Magazine has been a God-send to them. They have learned to do much of their reading from it."
In the Australian Mission, where 337½ per cent was obtained: "I wrote letters to members 1300 miles south and 1800 miles north." This representative reported one fourteen-year-old girl as subscribing for two aged people; also a fifteen-year-old investigator who purchased the Magazine for the Sidney Library in addition to her own subscription.
The Magazine has so many uses. It radiates the spirit of Relief Society and the spirit of the Gospel. Read the Magazine for its stimulating effect as well as for information and inspiration.
THE MAGAZINE IN THE MISSION
By Lewella R. Christiansen—Texas Mission
The Magazine is an effective aid in missionary work, especially in teaching women of the world the practical, cultural and spiritual sides of Mormonism. It is a real missionary. Sometimes women of other beliefs are hesitant to read the regular missionary tracts and pamphlets but are attracted by the poems, stories, lessons and articles of the Magazine. In this way the Gospel truths are presented in an indirect manner which makes an appeal, and a simple foundation is laid for the missionaries to build upon.
In one of the branches in Louisiana, we have a Sister whose husband is in the paper business and also mayor of the city. Recently she was asked to join some of the very fine clubs. She said to me, "I was asked to give a talk to my club and I found material for that talk in the Relief Society Magazine and was highly complimented. I also gave a talk at the P. T. A. Meeting, again taking the material from the same source."
The distribution of sample copies helped prepare the way for the organization of the Gonzales Relief Society. Realizing that there were a great many things in it that would build people, I wondered what was the best way to have everyone read it. So I outlined a program, to be given solely by Relief Society women at a Sunday service. The talks were short and well prepared and based on carefully selected articles from the Magazine. The program proved interesting and uplifting and acquainted those who listened with the rich content of the Magazine, besides giving the most timid women a chance to participate.
The Magazine has been used: as gifts for birthdays and Christmas, and to bring cheer to those who are numbered among the shut-ins. One can receive comfort and culture from the Magazine. I think the Lord inspires those who write the wonderful material found in it.
RELIEF SOCIETY MAGAZINE
GENERAL INSTRUCTIONS
Belle S. Spafford, Editor
In order to give both large and small wards equal opportunity to participate in the awards given at April Conference we are now dividing the wards into groups according to enrollment. There will be three groups, A, B, C.
Group A will include all wards or branches with a total enrollment of 100 or more.
Group B will include all wards or branches with a total enrollment of 50 to 99, inclusive.
Group C will include all wards or branches with a total enrollment up to 49.
To the four Ward or Branch Agents in each group obtaining the highest percentage, provided they have a minimum of 25 subscriptions, a bound volume of the Relief Society Magazine will be presented at the Relief Society General Conference held in April.
To all Ward or Branch Agents not receiving a bound volume, who obtain subscriptions equal to 75 per cent or above of their net enrollment, provided such subscription lists contain a minimum of 25 names, a one-year subscription to the Relief Society Magazine will be awarded. In case the Agent does not want the free subscription herself, it may be sent to some one designated by her.
Report Forms. New report forms for both wards and stakes will be sent to the stake representatives this year. We are indebted to Sister Christina V. Wilson of Bonneville Stake for suggesting these very fine forms. They are self-explanatory and must be very carefully filled out. Only stake reports should be returned to this office. Ward reports should be filled out and sent to the stake in sufficient time for the stake representative to compile and send her report to our office not later than November 10, 1938, otherwise wards cannot be included on the Honor Roll published in December nor receive free subscriptions.
Enrollment figures are based on active, honorary, and inactive enrollment. The enrollment as of January 1, 1938, will be used in figuring 1938 percentages. These figures must be identical with those given in the Secretaries' annual report.
Order Blanks. Send subscriptions on order blanks, furnished by our office. Writing should be legible. State the proper address of the individual to whom the Magazine is to be sent, the street number, if there is one, and the name of the town and the state. Please state the month when the subscription is to begin. Failure to do this often causes duplication, the subscriber receiving two numbers of one or more issues.
Receipts. Keep all receipts sent by this office. These are a check for us and for you in case of errors. Complaints must be made within two months in order to be rectified.

CORRELATION OF MUSIC TO LESSON MATERIAL
By Rose D. Ostler
Humanity everywhere is athirst for music. It might justly be called a holy cause, requiring a spirit of consecration. The field from which to gather song and music material is as broad as the field of music itself. Relief Society songs and music soften, glorify and feed the souls of our sisters. They add charm, a melodious background, and create a spiritual setting for the lessons.
In preparing for the use of songs in Relief Society, various plans have been carried out in Union meeting. It is suggested that stake music directors read very carefully the lessons before Union meeting and confer with the various class leaders as to the objectives of their lessons and secure suggestions for songs. The ward chorister may also be asked to read the lessons and confer with her ward class leaders and aid in bringing in suggestions for music to Union meeting. New songs may be introduced at this meeting. Write the words of the song on a blackboard, play the song as the preliminary music. After it has been played through once or twice many spontaneously join in the singing.
Hymns are always appropriate for the opening song of every ward Relief Society meeting. Especially do hymns and sacred music vitalize and beautify Theological lessons. Hymns are a treasure house of spiritual truth and beauty.
The songs our mothers and grandmothers used to sing can bring a wealth of joy to the Work and Business meeting, echoing the past. We find sweet music in the songs of long ago. Besides these lovely family songs, we may use some written by our women. This would be a fitting place for their inspired contributions.
A special music program suggests itself for the Literary lessons. Characters and the historical period in which the book was written provide suggestions. New songs of various types, solos, ensemble numbers, both vocal and instrumental, furnish a wealth of music material which may be used in the music department.
Lessons portrayed in the form of a tableau accompanied by music are very effective. Songs of our country and songs of home are appropriate for the Social Service lessons.
A typed outline given out each month at Union meeting, might include material to build a background of music for the chorister as well as for the lessons. Current musical events of the various wards, stories of the hymns and of the composers are interesting.
The calling of the chorister is a sacred one. To her falls the joy of bringing correlation of lesson and song, and of bringing the beauty that testifies to the reality of the spiritual life.
SOCIAL WELFARE DEPARTMENT
Amy W. Evans, Chairman
President Louise Y. Robison was the first speaker in this department meeting. She briefly discussed the subject, "The Relief Society and Child Welfare," a subject very dear to her heart. The Relief Society has always given very special attention to child welfare in its study program and in its activities, stressing the Word of Wisdom, cooperating extensively with state and federal agencies in carrying forth the work. She concluded with an earnest appeal for women to put forth every effort in setting higher standards for this work.
RELIEF SOCIETY CONFERENCE
NUTRITION AND ITS RELATION TO CHILD WELFARE
By Dr. William McKay
As public health workers we are delighted to know that the mothers are devoting so much of their activities to the study and solution of vital health problems. By giving place on your program to the subject of nutrition and child welfare, I think I can safely assume that you, as representatives of the Social Welfare Department of the Relief Society of the Church, are convinced that throughout our state there is ample evidence among our children of the lack of proper nutrition. A study of the reports of the many health agencies and dental clinics showing the numbers of physical defects, the prevalence of malnutrition, and the very high percentage of our child population with carious teeth should be sufficient to convince anyone that education on the subject of nutrition is urgently needed.
The first question which naturally arises in our minds is, "What is the meaning of the word nutrition?" One of the best definitions I have found is that given by Sir Robert McCarrison who defined nutrition as the fundamental function on which the condition of the body, that is to say, health depends. It is not merely food, nor that which nourishes. Food is the instrument of nourishment, nutrition is the act of using it—the series of coordinated processes whereby the nourishment of the body is effected. A primary purpose of the function of nutrition is: thus, to establish and to sustain the structure and function of all organs and parts of the body—to keep, in short, the mechanisms of the body in perfect running order.
Since body development and function begin months before that body is born into the world it is of the greatest importance that our expectant mothers have a clear understanding of the importance of diet during pregnancy. Sherman of Columbia University has shown the very marked physical differences in the offspring from mothers afforded an adequate diet as compared with the offspring of mothers with an inadequate diet. Sound healthy bodies with strong, well built bones, and teeth are the birthright of every child. The foundation for these is laid long before the child is born. Every expectant mother develops a mental image of the sort of boy or girl she would like to bear. Naturally, she hopes, and may I say—prays, that her child will be strong, sturdy, well shaped, of sound frame and have beautiful teeth. Not every mother realizes that the care she takes of herself during pregnancy to ensure a safe delivery is also a vital part of the planning necessary for sound bones and teeth. Regulated diets, under competent medical supervision, mean sufficient quantities of all the essential elements needed for proper growth and development of the body and the proper formation and calcifying of the teeth and bones. Systematic schedules of rest, sleep, exercise, and fresh air are essential for the mother, and these in turn play a part in the development of the expected child. If we accept the report of our dentists that fewer than twenty-five per cent of our children have sound teeth, I feel sure that this number might be greatly increased, if our expectant mothers realized that the formation of their babies' permanent teeth begins as early as the fourth month of fetal life.
The problem of adequate nutrition becomes even more complex after birth. If the mother elects to nurse her baby and has an adequate supply of milk which the child can tolerate, the problem for the first few months is comparatively simple. She must not, however, forget the importance of the protective elements found in cod liver oil, orange and tomato juices. Felding, a German investigator, reports that of 86,000 infants in Germany in 1935 who died before reaching one year of age, one-half succumbed to dietary disturbances, caused in very many instances by lack of breast feeding.
The importance of diet as the child develops is aptly expressed by Dr. W. McKim Marriott: "As the pediatrician deals with the body during the growing period, he may be compared with the builder of edifices; the internist and surgeon with the repair men. Given a solidly constructed structure, it will last well, and the minimum of repair work will be required. We cannot alter the general plans of the architect, but we can see that the proper materials go into the construction. Two buildings of the same size, and outward appearance may differ greatly, depending upon the care taken in construction; the one may approach perfection in structure and wear well, the other, because of the use of poor materials will not withstand wear and tear. It is so with the child's body; the architectural plan of nature may be excellent, but with skimping on materials a poor structure may result."
Adequate nutrition implies far more than the attainment and maintenance of a certain body size and weight or a certain thickness of adipose tissue. A child may be of average stature for the age and have an average height-weight ratio, yet, the nutrition cannot be considered as satisfactory if the child is anemic, has weak, flabby muscles, poor posture, carious teeth, has but little resistance to infection, and is incapable of sustained physical or mental effort. The growing body must be supplied with necessary building materials to perfect its structure and to provide adequately for functional activity. If the total fuel or caloric value of the food is inadequate to provide for the energy exchange, the laying down of body tissues is of necessity interfered with, or else tissues already formed are destroyed to meet the energy demands.
What are the materials necessary for proper and adequate nutrition? They are oxygen, water, and the digestion products of proteins, fats, carbohydrates, mineral elements and vitamins. These may be derived from the following food stuffs:
(1) A good whole-cereal grain or mixture of whole-cereal grains or a good whole-meal bread. (2) Milk and the products of milk—butter, cheese, buttermilk, etc. (3) Eggs. (4) Green leaf vegetables. (5) Root vegetables such as potatoes, carrots, etc. (6) Legumes—such as peas, beans, etc. (7) Fruit. (8) Meat. (9) Water.
That these provide all elements and vitamins needed for normal nutrition is evident from the fact that they are the ingredients of the national diets of certain races of northern India whose physique and health, when they make use of their national diets in their entirety, are unsurpassed by any other races of mankind.
Detailed information on adequate diets as well as suggestions on how to make them appetizing to children can be secured from circulars and pamphlets furnished by our own State Board of Health as well as by the U. S. Public Health Service and Department of Agriculture.
The appetite serves, in general, as a good guide to the total amount of food needed, and providing a suitable dietary mixture is offered there is little danger of under or overfeeding when the amount of food taken is regulated by the appetite of a normal infant or child. Normal infants and children, given all they wish to eat of a well balanced diet, are not likely to become overnourished.
It is often stated that the instinct serves as a fairly reliable guide in the selection of foods, and examples are cited of primitive people with no knowledge of nutrition who instinctively choose well balanced diets and even of young children who, given free selection, choose diets which meet their nutritional requirements. While in general the instinct may lead the individual to select a complete diet this cannot always be relied upon. In most families, mothers must be constantly on the alert if every child in the family receives an adequate supply of all the necessary elements of a balanced diet.
When President Brigham Young said, "This is the place," he probably little realized that the land of Deseret could be made to produce every necessary nutritional element for his people. That being true, it is a reflection on our intelligence when we must admit that there are large groups of children in almost every community in the state suffering from some degree of malnutrition. It is an interesting fact that children in many of our rural and farming areas are actually malnourished from the lack of milk and vegetables. Then too, we must not overlook the economic factor in our present social set-up. It is tragic, but true, that in many of our poorer homes, the diet consists almost wholly of bread and potatoes. Under a proper functioning of our Church Security program such conditions ought not to exist.
The problem of proper nutrition of our children resolves itself largely into one of education. I know of no organization which, in cooperation with our state and local health agencies, is in a better position or better qualified to carry on such an educational program than the Relief Society of the Church! What greater objective could any relief organization have than the development of generations of normal, well developed, healthy children? While spiritual growth is not dependent upon proper physical development, I feel sincerely that the Creator intended that His children should be physically sound and well in order that they might be mentally and spiritually strong.
RELIEF SOCIETY MAGAZINE
ADEQUATE PERSONALITY DEVELOPMENT—ITS RELATION TO CHILD WELFARE
By Ora W. Chipman
"For every child understanding and the guarding of his personality as his most precious right."—The Children's Charter.
One of the major objectives in the field of child welfare is that of attempting to secure for every child the development of a personality and of a character capable of meeting every stress and strain of life with confidence and eventual happiness—a personality which will enable him to realize his highest possibilities.
A good concept of personality was submitted at the White House Conference by Dr. Bronson Crothers, who defined it as, "the individual with all his emotional and intellectual peculiarities, trying to realize happiness and efficiency in the environment in which he lives."
Everyone, then, has personality; everyone—even he who seems to fail—is trying to create a successful life. The fortunate individual with the healthful mental attitudes of an adequate personality will succeed.
It is now the belief of many psychologists that adult behavior is the direct result of seeds of behavior planted in early childhood. The opinion of experts at the White House Conference was that factors that distort personality development exercise their greatest effects during the first six or seven years of life, and that those are the best years for development of desirable character traits and for modification of undesirable traits already established.
It has been estimated by authorities that there is a vast number of mentally ill people, not under treatment, who are suffering from serious but wholly avoidable distortions of personality probably caused by faulty training in childhood. There are, also, vast numbers of children who are seriously delinquent and of children and adolescents who are inmates of mental hospitals. One child out of every three is considered by child welfare representatives at the White House Conference to have personality difficulties which are serious enough to require the attention of a psychiatrist. These estimates help us to realize the significance of the development of healthful mental attitudes in childhood.
Conclusions from surveys to discover qualities generally considered as attributes of an attractive personality indicate that the most outstanding are: attractive physical appearance, intelligence, pleasing temperament, and sound character. Of these temperament and character are the most important. It is a common belief that temperament is inherited, but it now seems probable that this assumption is incorrect. "Temperamental reactions are learned habits formed in the early years. Much of the fundamental nature of temperament has been determined by the end of the first three years." The child's temperament consists of his attitudes toward the various phases of life. These attitudes are developed, not born. "Children who are gloomy or optimistic, suspicious or trustful, timid or courageous, loving or hateful, have been taught these modes of feeling, or they have stumbled into them, for these characteristics are not inherent in child nature." Regarding character much has been written and detail will be unnecessary here. The most admirable

RELIEF SOCIETY CONFERENCE
and most successful characters seem to be based on attitudes of love and trust both in a supreme being and in fellow man. Fundamental also is faith in their own ability to live happy useful lives. But even these characteristics are implanted in early childhood.
Diverging from the positive values of character let us consider some of the most outstanding pitfalls into which children drift and often remain with consequent damage to their personalities. Some of these are excessive modesty, suspiciousness, bashfulness, withdrawing into one's self, desire to play alone, constant whining, fears, day dreaming, demands for attention, sensitiveness, sulkiness, and anger. Of these fear and anger seem to be most damaging. Fear has played such an important part in breaking down personality that eminent students of mental health speak of it as the "chaos of fear," and the "bogey of fear." Many fears are in the subconscious,
347
influencing lives without the conscious knowledge of the person. It probably produces more unhappiness and more abnormalities than any other known cause. It can be overcome by proper treatment. A fear carefully examined usually disappears. A fear should be replaced with a situation which a child can meet with confidence, keeping his faith in God and restoring his faith in himself. We should provide in our training for the formation of the habit of facing difficulties now and practically, for the need of constructive work, and for habits of normal reaction to feeling—or healthful emotions.
It is our aim in child welfare work to help mothers lay the foundations for these healthful mental attitudes of normal buoyant personalities equipped to develop the greatest possibilities of life. The more we learn of the exact science of creating adequate well integrated personalities in our children the more progress we make, the happier we help to make the lives of generations now and to come.
